comments:
This course covers the fundamentals of biological chemistry, including the structure of biological macromolecules and their mechanism of action, intermediary metabolism, and the chemical basis of information transfer.

Many students found this course to be “very interesting” and thought that the “emphasis on general concepts” helped them to “understand the bigger picture more clearly.” Some students complained about the switching of professors halfway through the semester because it made it “difficult to know what to study for exams.” Others complained about the lack of a dedicated textbook and assigned readings, as many of them had a “hard time knowing what to study” for exams.

Students found Professor Saven to be “very knowledgeable” and “passionate.” However, some students felt that he was “not always organized,” making it “difficult sometimes to follow his lectures.”

In general, students believed that exams “accurately reflected the material covered,” even though some considered them to be “extremely difficult.” Some students also felt that without previous biology and organic chemistry knowledge, they had “to play catch-up all semester.”
